name: Louis Pasteur
description: Louis Pasteur was born in 1822 in Dole, France. He earned his undergraduate degree in Bachelors of Letters .Sir Pasteur is one of the most significant contributors to the field of microbiology. He has done extensive research in public health and microbiology. He is considered as one of the founders of modern bacteriology and has been honored as “Father of Bacteriology” and “Father of Microbiology”. He developed the “The Modern Germ Theory of Disease”. He has also contributed in the fields of Pasteurization, Vaccination, Sterilization, Silk Industry and Isomerism. Sir Pasteur won several award during his lifetime and this space wont be sufficient enough to list all of them. Yet, one of the significant awards of his life was being the fellowship of the Royal society of London.

name: Alexander Fleming
description: Alexander felming.

name: Antonie Van Leeuwenhoek
description: Antonie Van Leeuwenhoek was born in 1632 in Delft, Dutch Republic. Talking about his education, Leeuwenhoek never attended any university. He was unaware of other scientific research and rather re-investigated already existing phenomena. He has contributed extensively in the field of microscopy. He designed hand-made microscopes that he used to observe samples like dental plaques and water. Additionally, he was the first to give microscopic observations of organisms and/or cells like bacteria, RBCs, spermatozoa etc. He was also among the first to witness blood flow among capillaries.  He is also credited as being the first person to observe and document the existence of microorganisms. Leeuwenhoek had techniques for lens grinding and microscope construction that were significantly essential for advancing microscopy.Alongside this, his groundbreaking discoveries about the microscope expanded our understanding about microscopes and led to working for better designs.

name: Edward Jenner
description: Edward Jenner-Born on 17th May,1749, Jenner became an orphan at the age of 5 . During his school years, Jenner developed a strong interest in science and nature, which later helped him pioneer the concept of vaccines and later the small pox vaccine, the world's first vaccine.Jenner is known as father of immunology due to his efforts of saving millions of people from the threatening disease of small pox.

name: Ignaz Philipp Semmelweis
description: EJ

name: Hans Christian Joachim Gram
description: Hans Christian Joachim Gram was born on 13th September 1853, Copenhagen, Denmark and died at the age of 85 years on 14 November 1938, Copenhagen, Denmark. He did his studies at the University of Copenhagen. He was assigned as botany assistant to the zoologist Japetus Steenstrup. Because of his study about plants, he learned the basics of pharmacology and the use of the microscope. His main field of career was bacteriology. In 1878, Gram started his medical school and completed his graduation in 1883.In Berlin, Gram developed a method for distinguishing between two major bacterial classes in 1884. This technique is called Gram staining, which divides bacteria into gram positive and gram negative on the basis of capacity to take up stains, which is still a standard technique of medical microbiology. Because of his work he achieved an international reputation. The staining method later played a major role in classifying bacteria. Gram was a modest man, and in his initial publication he remarked, 'I have therefore published the method, although I am aware that as yet it is very defective and imperfect; but it is hoped that also in the hands of other investigators it will turn out to be useful. Gram staining uses a primary stain that is of crystal violet and a counterstain of safranin. Bacteria that turn purple when stained are known as 'Gram-positive', while those that turn red are termed 'Gram-negative'. His  initial work was about the study of human red blood cells. He was one of the first who recognised that macrocytes were characteristic of pernicious anemia. During 1891, Gram taught pharmacology, and he was appointed as professor at the University of Copenhagen. In 1900, he left his professorship of pharmacology and became professor of medicine.As a professor, he published four volumes of clinical lectures. He retired from the University of Copenhagen in 1923.

name: Charles Louis Alphonse Laveran
description: Charles louis alphonse larveran was a french physician, pathologist and parasitologist who was born on 18th june, 1845, paris, france and died at the age of 76 on 18th may, 1922. He completed his medical studies form university of strasbourg. In the franco-german war, he served as an army surgeon and till 1897 he joined the pasteur institute, paris, where he practiced and taught about military medicine. When he was serving as a military surgeon in Algeria, he discovered the causative agents of infectious disease such as malaria and trypanosomiasis which are parasitic protozoans. He discovered that plasmodium was responsible for malaria and trypanosoma was responsible for trypanosomiasis or african sleeping sickness. He became chief of honorary service at pasteur institute, where he won the nobel prize. He established the laboratory of tropical medicine at pasteur institute from half of his Nobel prize money. He was selected as a member of the French Academy of Sciences in 1893, and later, also became Commander of the National Order of the Legion of Honour in 1912.

name: Joseph Lister
description: Joseph Lister was born on 5 april, 1827, upton, essex, england and died on 10 february 1912.He was a British surgeon and medical scientist. He is founder of antiseptic medicine and preventive medicines. Earlier some of his published work was about the mechanism of coagulation of blood and role of the blood vessels in the first stage of inflammation. After that he began his experiments with antisepsis. Both of his works were directly connected with the healing of wounds. His attempt to interpose an antiseptic barrier between the wounds and air. He protected the site of operations from infection by the surgeon’s hands and instruments. He also found antiseptic effects in carbolic acid and advised on wound dressing in 1863. His antisepsis work was used on a large scale during the franco-german war. He was the first to apply the science of germ theory to surgery. His principles made surgery safe and continue to save countless lives.

name: Fanny Hesse
description: Fanny was a microbiologist who was born on 22nd june, 1850, new york as ‘Angelina Fanny Eilshemius’ and died on 1st december, 1934. She studied French and home economics at finishing school in switzerland.In 1872, while traveling in Germany with Eugenie, she met Eugenie's brother, her future husband and research partner, Walther Hess. The couple became engaged in 1873, and they married in 1874 with a wedding held in Geneva finally becoming fanny hess. In addition to her housekeeping duties, Hesse gives her best to assist her husband through preparing bacterial growth media, cleaning equipment, and producing illustrations for scientific publications. After  becoming familiar with her husband's work she performed a role similar to a modern-day medical technologist, She also performed a role as a scientific illustrator, drawing highly accurate watercolor images showing each growth phase of intestinal bacterial culture when viewed under magnification, and her illustrations were included in her husband's work that was published in 1908 as part of her work in the development of medical illustration. Hess helped to coat test tubes with gelatin for her husband to use in growing microorganisms but they discovered that gelatin easily melted on warm days, destroying some of the bacteria. With her technical duties, she also helped through her artistic abilities to draw the same pictures of bacterial colonies as viewed under a microscope in the different phases of bacteria growth to use in her husband's journal publications. She recommended agar as a plating medium and she was also helping her husband to culture air-borne bacteria. In 1881, while her husband was working in the laboratory of  Robert Koch who was a German physician and microbiologist, they  had tried to use potato slices as a medium to culture pure colonies but it was unsubstantial, they tried  to use a nutrient-rich gelatin media, which still did not provide adequate stability for producing cultures for examination. After so many unsuccessful attempts of culturing microorganisms on gelatin mediums, Hesse suggested that agar was preferable to gelatin for cultivating bacteria and other microorganisms. She was knowing about the properties of agar as a gelling agent, able to maintain its physical properties at warm temperatures, through her usage of it at home. She had learned about agar from her mother’s friend. She was first to suggest using agar as an alternative to gelatin; they were first to use agar as a common gelling agent for producing media capable of culturing microorganisms at high temperatures. The main difference between agar and gelatin was agar could remain solid at temperatures up to 90°C while settling at temperatures below 45°C, gelatin liquified at 37°C, which made it an unsuitable medium to plate many types of bacteria in laboratory conditions. The agar 'dessert medium' invented by Hesse.

name: Martinus Willem Beijerinck
description: Martinus Willem Beijerinck was born in 1851 in Holland, Amsterdam.  He completed his graduation from Delft and obtained doctorate from the University of Leiden in 1877.He was also one of the founders of virology and environmental microbiology. He founded the discipline of virology with his discovery of viruses (TMV). he called that virus “contagium vivum fluidum”. Beijerinckia (a genus of bacteria), beijerinckiaceae (a family of hyphomicrobiaceae) and Beijerinck crater are named after him. The M.W.Beijerinck virology prize is also awarded in his honor. Earlier he studied plant galls, swellings of plant tissue now known to be caused by the invasion of various infectious agents. He isolated bacillus radicicola, the nodule organism of leguminous plants in 1888. His studies are essential for soil science, azotobacter, sulfur bacteria and on denitrification (which convert soil nitrates to free atmospheric nitrogen). He was the first who said that viruses are reproducing entities, but it is different from other living organisms. He also visited the laboratory of German bacteriologist Robert Koch to learn. His works and scientific reputation were expanding and  in 1895 the Dutch government created a special position for him at the delft polytechnical school. He remained there till his retirement in 1921.

name: Marjory Stephenson
description: MS

name: Kiyoshi Shiga
description: KS

name: Sergei Nikolaievich Winogradsky
description: SNW

name: Emil von Behring
description: Emil von Behring was born in Hansdorf in 1854.Behring received his medical degree in 1878 from the Friedrich-Wilhelms-Institute, and became an assistant to Robert Koch in 1889.  Behring, became an assistant at the Institute for Infectious Diseases. He started his studies with development of a therapeutically active first of a kind serum against diphtheria.  He received many awards, few significant being the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for his work on serum therapy-first of the Nobel Prizes given in the field of immunology.

name: Sir Ronald Ross
description: RR

name: Heinrich Hermann Robert Koch
description: Robert Koch was born in 1843, in Clausthal, Northwest Germany. He had a natural interest in natural science and entered the University of Göttingen to study the same. But later on he changed his area of study to medicine. Sir Koch performed elaborate inoculation studies using several animal species and discovered rod shaped bacterium in the blood of affected animals. Alongside this, he also discovered the route of their transmission. He studied illness caused by microorganisms, discovered and described   TB bacterium in 1882. In 1883 he discovered an organism which causes cholera and worked on how it is transmitted and also developed a vaccination for rinderpest. His main works Known are Koch's postulates, Koch–Pasteur rivalry ,Bacterial culture method, Germ theory of disease, Medical microbiology ,Discovery of anthrax bacillus ,Discovery of tuberculosis bacillus and tuberculin for which he won nobel prize. Koch was made a Knight Grand Cross in the Prussian Order of the Red Eagle,  on 19 November 1890, It was awarded to both military personnel and civilians, to recognize valor in combat, excellence in military leadership, long and faithful service to the kingdom and elected a Foreign Member of the Royal Society (ForMemRS) in 1897.  He won The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 1905 for his investigations and discoveries in relation to tuberculosis (TB). In order to honor Robot Koch, In 1906, because of his research on tuberculosis and tropical diseases, he was honored by the Order Pour le Merite. The Robert Koch Foundation, founded in 1907, is a not for profit foundation for the promotion of medical progress in Berlin. The Foundation has the goal of supporting the fight against infectious diseases and other epidemics This Foundation awards each year a number of prestigious scientific awards: the Robert Koch Award, one of the highest-ranking scientific awards in Germany, the Robert Koch Gold Medal in 1980. The Robert Koch Award is one of the most esteemed scientific awards in the Federal Republic of Germany. The prize is awarded annually to researchers for outstanding and internationally recognized scientific achievements. Emperor Wilhelm I also awarded him the Order of the Crown, 100,000 marks and appointment as Privy Imperial Councillor, Surgeon-General of Health Service, and Fellow of the Science Senate of Kaiser Wilhelm Society.

name: Julius Wagner-Jauregg
description: JWJ

name: Charles Jules Henri Nicolle
description: CHARLES JULES HENRI NICOLLE was born in 1866 in Rouen, France. His works include many significant scientific contributions like discovery of the mode of  transmission of typhus fever and tick fever. He even introduced vaccination for Malta fever.Alongside these, Sir Charles has also studied cancer, scarlet fever, rinderpest, measles, influenza, tuberculosis and trachoma and identified the parasitic organism Toxoplasma gondii within the tissues of the gundi (Ctenodactylus gundi) one commonly found in AIDS patients.He was awarded with several awards, one of the prestigious being the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine.

name: Gerhard Johannes Paul Domagk
description: GJPD

name: Sir Ernst Boris Chain
description: Sir Ernst Boris chain was a British biochemist who was born on 19th june, 1906, in berline and died at the age of 73 on 12th august, 1979, casterbar, ireland. He studied chemistry at Friedrich Wilhelm university. When nazis came in power, Chain knew that he was not safe in Germany and went to England on 2nd april, 1933. With the help of J.B.S. haldane, he obtained a position at university college hospital, landon. After that, he studied at fitzwilliam college, cambridge as PhD student and there he started working on phospholipids under the guidance of sir frederick gowland hopkins. In 1935, he became lecturer of pathology at oxford university. During this period he worked on many topics including tumor metabolism, lysozymes, snake venoms and biochemistry techniques. In 1939, he investigated natural antibacterial agents which was synthesized by microorganisms with Howard florey. Chain and florey together worked on therapeutic action and its chemical composition. They discovered techniques to isolate and concentrate the germ killing agents in penicillin. For this work, both chain and florey won the nobel prize in physiology or medicine. Chain was also working on theorizing the beta-lactam structure of penicillin in 1942, which was later confirmed by Dorothy hodgkin through x- ray crystallography. Towards the end of world war II, he got to know that his mother and sister had been killed by nazis. He returned to Britain in 1964 and became founder and head of the biochemistry department at Imperial college, london. He stayed there till his retirement and also did specialization in fermentation technologies.

name: Howard Walter Florey, Baron Florey
description: HWF

name: Max Theiler
description: HWF

name: Selman Abraham Waksman
description: SELMAN ABRAHAM WAKSMAN was born in 1888 in Nova Pryluka, Ukraine. He graduated with a science in agriculture degree from Rutgers University, followed by a master's degree from the same university. He later was awarded a doctor of philosophy in biochemistry.Selman has spent his time researching about various aspects of decomposition of soil living organisms. This research led to the discovery of streptomycin and several other antibiotics. He even introduced procedures that have led to the development of many others antibiotics. He also spent his time studying soil fungi.Selman received awards like the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine, Leeuwenhoek Medal and Albert Lasker Award for Basic Medical Research. He was also known as an inventor, biochemist and microbiologist.

name: Stanley Norman Cohen
description: STANLEY NORMAN COHEN was born in 1935 in New Jersey, United States. He graduated with a BS degree and later moved to complete an MD from University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine. He worked with nerve growth factor and epidermal growth factor. He is an American biochemist who, along with Rita Levi-Montalcini, was awarded the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for the isolation of nerve growth factor and the discovery of epidermal growth factor. In 1979 elected to the National Academy of Sciences. Alongside these, Stanley Norman Cohen also received Wolf Prize in Medicine, National Inventors Hall of Fame and many more.

name: Herbert Wayne 'Herb' Boyer
description: HB

name: Georges Jean Franz Köhler
description: George Jean Franz Kohler was a german biologist who was born on 17th april, munich, germany and died at the age of 48 on 1st march 1995 at freiburg, Breisgau due to heart problem. He did his post doctoral research at the laboratory of molecular biology in Cambridge, UK. There he developed laboratory tools for investigating the mechanism of diversity of antibodies. During his work he invented hybridoma techniques for the production of antibodies, in april 1974. He worked on development of transgenic mice as a tool to understand the mechanism of self tolerance. In 1986, Kohler was appointed as director of the max planck institute of immunobiology where he worked until his death.

name: César Milstein
description: CESAR MILSTEIN was born in 1927 in Bahía Blanca, Argentina. He developed a hybridoma technique for the production of monoclonal antibodies and also worked over antibody research.  He won several awards like the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine and earned several fellowships like Fellowship of Royal Society in 1975.

name: Pushpa Mittra Bhargava
description: Pushpa Mittra Bhargava was born in 1928 in Ajmer. He was a postdoctorate in synthetic organic chemistry.  He is the founder of Centre for Cellular and Molecular Biology, a federally funded research institute, in Hyderabad .He was awarded the Padma Bhushan and the Legion of Honour, among the many many laurels and titles .

name: Károly Ereky
description: KE

name: Rudolf Jaenisch
description: He is a professor of biology at MIT and was born on 22 april, 1942. He received his doctorate in medicine from the University of Munich in 1967 in the lab of German researcher P.H. Hofschneider. He was head of the department of tumor virology at the heinrich pette institute at university of hamburg, after that he became a founding member of Whitehead institute. He is known for epigenetic mechanisms of gene regulation, therapeutic cloning and embryonic stem cell research. He focused on creating genetically modified mice to study cancer epigenetic reprogramming and neurological diseases. He won many awards like gruber prize in genetics in 2001, robert koch prize in 2002, max delbruck medal in 2006, massry prize in 2008 from the keck school medicine, wolf prize in medicine in 2011 and got national medal of science in 2011. He made his scientific career in fields of biochemistry, medicine and genetics.  He created the first transgenic model and performed the first experiment to show that genetic defects could be corrected by therapeutic cloning in mice. His work has led to major advancement in our understanding of embryonic stem cells and in induced pluripotent stem (IPS) Cells. It appears identical to embryonic stem cell but can be formed from adult cells without using eggs.

name: Paul Berg
description: Paul Berg was born in 1926 in New York, United States. He earned a bachelors degree in biochemistry and later a doctorate in biochemistry as well. He contributed to the 1980 Nobel Prize in Chemistry, along with Walter Gilbert and Frederic Sanger. He also worked nucleic acids, DNA splicing and nucleic acid base sequences and recombinant DNA technology.In 1966, he became a member of the American Academy of Business and Science and the National Academy of Sciences. He was also admitted as a member of the American Philosophical Association. He won the American Academy of Achievement's Gold Plate award in 1989 and was named a Foreign Fellow of the Royal Society (ForMemRS) in 1992. In 2005, he was awarded the Biotechnology Heritage Award by the Biotechnology Industry Organization (BIO) and the Chemical Heritage Foundation. In 2006, he received Wonderfest's Carl Sagan Award for Scientific Research. He died on February 15, 2023 at  Stanford, California, United States.

name: Vinay K. Nandicoori
description: Vinay kumar nandicoori is an indian immunologist, biotechnologist and currently the director of center of cellular and molecular biology. He was born on 1st march 1969. He did his M.Sc in biotechnology from Indian institute of technology (IIT), Bombay, India and PhD from the Indian institute of science. After PhD he worked at the University of Virginia and Texas A&M university. His known studies are on the kinase-mediated signaling networks in mycobacterium tuberculosis, the causative pathogen of tuberculosis. The department of biotechnology of India honored him with the national bioscience award for career development which is one of the highest indian science awards for his contribution to biosciences in 2010.  National academy of science, India elected him as a member of Guha research conference and awarded the NASI-scopus young scientist award, which he received in 2009.

name: Sudhanshu Vrati
description: Sudhanshu vrati is a microbiologist, immunologist and the director of the regional center for biotechnology. He was born on 19th march 1960, uttar pradesh, india. He completed his M.Sc in microbiology from G.B. Pant university of agriculture and technology. He had also done DIIT in biochemistry engineering from Indian institute of technology (IIT), Delhi, india. He completed his doctoral studies from the Australian national university and secured PhD in biochemistry. After his PhD, he worked at commonwealth scientific and industrial research organization (CSIRO) center, sydney. When he returned to India, he joined the national institute of immunology as a scientist.He got the VASVIK Industrial Research Award in 2001. He also got one of the highest Indian science awards by The Department of Biotechnology of the Government of India, in 2003. He was selected by Indian National Science Academy for the Professor KP Bhargava Memorial Medal and by the Association of Microbiologists of India, the Alembic Award in 2005. While working as senior scientist, he was appointed as the dean at the translational health science and technology institute (THSTI) in 2005. The National Academy of Sciences, India once again honored him with the NASI-Reliance Platinum Jubilee Award in 2006.The Department of Biotechnology gave him the Tata Innovation Fellowship, in 2009 and the High Commission of Australia in India awarded him the Australian Alumni Award in 2010 . After that he was transferred to the regional center for biotechnology (RCB) as its executive director in October 2015. Earlier he researches at THSTI focused on mechanisms of receptor binding and entry, molecular mechanism of virus replication, assembly, egress as well as the clinical development of an oral rotavirus vaccine. After that he started concentrating on the development of DNA vaccines and his work was published as an article, DNA vaccines: getting closer to becoming a reality in 2013. His studies on rat brain helped to identify Mov34 protein later which was used in the development of vaccines for flaviviral diseases like Japanese encephalitis and Dengue.

name: Motilal Madan
description: Madan was born in 1939 in Srinagar. He is the recipient of PhD from University of Missouri. Madan served as Project Director of Embryo Transfer Technology at India's premier dairy research institute, the National Dairy Research Institute (NDRI). He led a research team at the institute that conducted the world's first successful in vitro fertilization of a buffalo, resulting in the birth of a calf, named 'Pratham, in November 1990. Sir Madan received several awards during his professional tenure and has even garnered fame through his publications of 432 research articles and policy papers in international and national refereed journals – including 226 original research papers. His pioneering research areas include  reproductive endocrinology, embryo biotechnology, in vitro fertilization and cloning.

name: Banwari Lal
description: BL

name: Keith Henry Stockman Campbel
description: Keith Henry Stockman Campbell was born in 1954 in Birmingham, England. He got educated in embryo growth and cell differentiation. He earned a bachelors in microbiology and an ultimate degree of PhD. He was the first to clone an animal in 1996 a Finnish Dorset sheep named. He was Professor of Animal Development at the University of Nottingham. He produced lambs from embryonic cells that differentiated in culture. He worked with cell cycle of embryonic cells. In 2008, he received the Shaw Prize in Medicine and Life Sciences together with Ian Wilmut and Shinya Yamanaka. In 2015, he was posthumously awarded the Pioneer Award by the International Embryo Transfer Society.

name: Sir Ian Wilmut
description: IW

name: Piet Bergveld
description: PB

name: Arthur D. Riggs
description: Arthur Dale Riggs was born in 1939 in California.Riggs completed his undergraduate degree in chemistry from University of California, and later his doctoral thesis work at the California Institute of Technology with Herschel K. Mitchell, and  obtained a  Ph.D. in biochemistry in 1966. In 1977, Sir Riggs created the first artificially synthesized gene and human protein which he later used for producing humulin-a first human insulin from bacteria.Sir Riggs later developed recombinant DNA technology that produced human monoclonal antibodies useful for diseases like cancers and HIV. He was recognized for this lifetime of achievements by his election to the National Academy of Sciences in 2006.Alongside this, he was felicitated with Distinguished Alumni Award from University of California, was elected to the National Academy of Sciences.

name: Emmanuelle Marie Charpentier
description: EMC

name: Jennifer Anne Doudna
description: JAD

name: Yuan Longping
description: Yuan Longping, internationally known as the ‘father of hybrid rice was a Chinese plant scientist whose breakthroughs in developing high-yield hybrid strains of rice helped to alleviate famine and poverty across much of Asia and Africa. Yuan Longping was born in Beijing in 1930 and received his agronomic degree from Southwest Agricultural College (now Southwest University) in 1953. Subsequently, he began his teaching career at Anjiang Agricultural School in Hunan Province, China.  Mr. Yuan’s work on hybrid rice started in the 1960 with the backdrop of an unprecedented famine. He reported findings on mutated male-sterile rice plants in the Chinese Science Bulletin in 1966. As these experiments did not show significant advantage over common rice, he started cross breeding with a wild rice species, known as ‘wild abortive’.Subsequent experiments, involving a large team of scientists and farmers across the country, proved successful as the new hybrid rice performed better than conventional rice. By 1979, this technique for hybrid rice was being introduced in the United States. Mr. Yuan’s rice accomplishments continued over the years.The late 1990s saw the launch of the Super Hybrid Rice Breeding Research Programme, under Mr. Yuan’s guidance, aiming to carry out national demonstration and promotion of the research results of super rice. In the next decade, China doubled rice production while reducing use of chemical fertilizers and pesticides.Yuan Longping’s hybrid rice varieties eventually became dominant in China’s paddies and in overall rice production. And China has dominated world hybrid rice production since 2004.Mr Yuan Longping was credited with a long list of awards and prizes, including China’s first special invention award in 1981, the UNESCO Prize for Science in 1987, the Nikkei Asia Award in 1996, the State Preeminent Science and Technology Award in 2000, the Wolf Prize in Agriculture and the Word Food Prize in 2004.Mr Yuan Longping passed away on 22 May 2021 at the age of 91, in Changsha, Hunan Province, China.

name: Kary Banks Mullis
description: KBM

name: Gottlieb Haberland
description: GH

name: Ross Granville Harrison
description: RGH

name: Ingo Potrykus
description: Ingo Potrykus is professor of plant science at plant science institute of swiss federal institute of technology (ETH), Zurich who was born on 5th december, 1933, in germany. He completed his degree in biology at university of cologne and completed his doctoral degree at the max-plansk institute for plant breeding research, cologne, germany. After several years being at institute of plant physiology, university of hohenhelm, he was appointed group leader at max-planck institute for plant genetics, ladenburg, germany. He went to Basel, Switzerland to establish a plant genetic engineering area at the federal institute of technology. He became professor at plant science which was focusing on biotechnology of plants. He retired from this institute in 1999 at the age of 65. Potrykus and his research team gave attention to genetic engineering yield stability and food quality of crops such as rice, wheat, millet, sorghum and cassava, because of the announcement of the upcoming crisis issue of malnutrition in developing countries. Golden rice is one of the most significant creations done till now. He took funding from the Rockefeller Foundation and combined with Peter Beyer and together launched a project to develop Golden Rice, that would become a seven-year, $2.6 million. He retired in 1999 and Ingo Potrykus became president of the International Humanitarian Golden Rice Board and devoted his energy to guiding Golden Rice to farmers across the many problems of a GMO-crop. He has established collaboration with 14 rice institutions in India, China, Vietnam, Bangladesh, Indonesia and Philippines.

name: Peter Beyer
description: PB

name: Frederick Sanger
description: FS

name: Gregor Mendel
description: Gregor Johann Mendel was the German Czech biologist who was born on 20th July 1822 at Heinzendorf, Bei Odrau, Silesia, Australian Empire which is now known as Czechia and died at an age of 61 on 6th January 1884 at Brno, Moravia, Austria-Hungary (now Czechia) due to chronic nephritis. Since he was born to a gardener's family, so he had limited resources, therefore he was raised in a rural setting but his academic abilities were recognised by the local priest and this made his parents to send him away to the school at an age of 11. Then he completed his 2 year program in philosophy at Philosophical institute of University of Olmutz and excelled in the field of physics and mathematics thereby completing his studies in 1843. He then moved on to the monastery to Brunn, capital of Moravia where he was freed from all the harsh struggle of life that he did in the previous years. At University of Vienna he devoted time to mathematics and physics along with which he studied anatomy and philosophy of plants and learnt how to use the microscope in the summer of 1853. In 1854 Mendel planned a major experiment on hybridization at his own ministry whose major aim was to know about the hybridization and transmission of characters in the following generations and choiced Pisum sativum that is edible pea plant mainly to conduct his studies upon, because of numerous distinct varieties, ease of culture and control of pollination with high proportion of the excessive germinations. With time as genetic studies were pushed down at molecular level, Mendelian's gene theory became acceptable and started being acknowledged as Father of Genetics

name: Rosalind Franklin
description:
Rosalind Franklin was a British chemist and X-ray crystallographer who was born on 25th July  1920 at Notting hills, London, England and died at an age of 37 due to ovarian cancer on 16th April1958 at Chelsea, London, England She did her graduation in a natural sciences from Newnham college, Cambridge in 1941 and even got herself enrolled for phD in physical chemistry under Ronald George but since she was too disappointed by Ronald's lack of diligence that she took up a research position under British coal utilization research association in 1942 in which she was able to earn a phD degree due to her research on coal. Then she moved on to Paris in 1947 as postdoctoral researcher and became a successful X-ray crystallographer. Though she was able to unearth some of the major properties of DNA which gradually helped to discover the correct description of the double helix structure of DNA, her work was unrecognized in her lifetime due to which she was given various names as 'wronged heroin', 'dark lady of DNA', 'forgotten heroin', 'feminist icon' and so on. In April 2023, based on the new evidence, scientists concluded that Franklin was a contributor and 'equal player' in the discovery process of DNA. Her work was mainly based on the understanding and discovery of concepts related to the molecular structures of DNA, RNA, viruses, coal and graphite and due to her hard work and devotion she got appreciation for the coal and viruses in her lifetime. Franklin's various contributions in the field of science includes the following: 
 1.She performed X-ray diffraction studies that provided some important clues regarding the structure of DNA.
 2.She also explained the effect of heating and carbonisation on the permeability of coal and carbon in which she found that the pores at molecular level have 5 constrictions which increase with the heating and they are known as 'molecular sieves'. Since she was the first one to identify these microstructures, so it became possible to classify coal and predict their performances with high degree of accuracy.
 3. She also introduced the words like graphitizing and non-graphitizing carbon which formed the basis for the development of carbon fibers and new heat resistant materials and it made her earn an International reputation among the coal chemists.
 4. She also analyzed the different patterns that revealed that tobacco mosaic virus's genetic material ieRNA was embedded in the protective protein shell's inner wall.
 5. Therefore, in her 16 year career, Franklin published 19 articles on coals and carbon, 5 on DNA and 21 on viruses. Even in her last few years she received the maximum number of invitations to speak at various conferences all over the world which was mainly due to her research work on viruses and that had earned tremendous awards and professional recognition. Her prominent publications include thermal 'expansion of coals and carbonized coals', 'study of 5 structure of carbonaceous solids by measurements of true and apparent densities: part one - coals', 'study of 5 structure of carbonaceous solids by measurements of true and apparent densities: part two - carbonized coals', 'the structure of graphitic carbons' and many more.

name: Daisy Roulland-Dussoix
description: Daisy Roulland-Dussoix (9 September 1936 at  Geneva, Switzerland – 5 January 2014 at  Lancy, Switzerland) was a Swiss molecular microbiologist. During her undergraduate education, she worked as a researcher on restriction enzymes. Daisy Roulland-Dussoix was born on September 9, 1936 in Geneva, Switzerland. His parents were Edmond Louis Dusoit and Elsa Magatha (Sauerbrey) Dusoit. Daisy Roulland-Dussoix (née Daisy Dussoix) received her first degree in chemistry and biology at the University of Geneva (1958), followed by her doctorate in biophysics (1964). While a graduate student at the University of Geneva, she discovered restriction enzymes, bacterial enzymes that attach to DNA. This discovery led to the advancement of molecular biology, opening the door to genome editing and cloning technology. His lawyer, Werner Arber, won the Nobel Prize in 1978 for this discovery. Later in her career, Daisy transferred to UCSF, where she worked on proto-oncogenes with Harold Varmus, who won the Nobel Prize in 1989. In 1980 Daisy moved to Paris and became director of the Mycoplasma Laboratory at the Pasteur Institute. She failed in January 2014. While working on his PhD with Swiss microbial geneticists Werner Arber and Eduard Kellenberger, he first demonstrated that immunity from bacteria (bacteriophages) led to the discovery that restriction and treatment of enzymes were important. Molecular Biology Tools. These enzymes affect the cleavage of DNA from specific sequences by enzymes at specific points, unless the enzymes are protected by enzymatic modification through the DNA base. This system prevents the spread of bacterial infections. Grete Kellenberger-Gujer's previous research showed that phage DNA can be degraded by the host's bacterial cells. Daisy Dussoix and Werner Arber showed in two publications that this process requires enzymes, paving the way for the discovery and isolation of relevant restriction and repair enzymes. They first presented these results at the First International Congress on Biophysics in Stockholm in 1961. In 1964, supported by a postdoctoral fellowship from Jane Pall Childs, Dussoit moved to Stanford University in the United States to work with Robert Lehman. From 1968 he was an assistant professor in the Department of Microbiology at the University of California, San Francisco, where he continued to work on DNA restriction and repair with Herbert W Boyer.
